text: So, you know, we went this entire calculus of going through all the vehicles that, you know, we kind of touched on at the first part of this podcast. We did that, right? And actually, I, from my seat in a solutions business at a bank, and Zed from his seat at three or four different kinds of roles, you know, everything from large asset managers to hedge funds. You know, we've both been looking at this problem from different angles for 15 years. And we've known each other that whole time. Zed was actually one of my early clients at Deutsche Bank. And I was approaching the end of my time in the capital release unit, and Zed was looking to figure out his next thing. And, you know, we just said, we started talking and went, well, if we threw out all the operational constraints, we just didn't pay attention to them for an hour, what would we build? What would we build in order to deliver the maximum capital efficiency? And tax efficiency and investment efficacy from an option strategy? Like, forget about the wrapper. Like, what would we want in order to be able to do that? And for all the reasons I've talked about before, the answer that we came to was, well, particularly when it comes to long convexity or long vol, you've really got to deliver it in an SMA. Because you can't take someone, you can't ask someone realistically to sell down part of their portfolio in order to fund the risk mitigating strategy. Like, that is a non-starter for most. And then even if they do that, they're not going to do it in sufficient size that you're going to have an opportunity set that you really want. You're just going to be able to do kind of one trade. So that doesn't work, right? So just out of the box, the funded vehicles don't work. And they also don't work for tax because the switching costs are very high. It's tough to ask someone to switch into your funded vehicle for your funded hedged equity vehicle if they've got to take a big realized tax hit to switch into it. Which, by the way, is... Is every family office in the United States, because since the financial crisis, they're all sitting on a portfolio that's at least 35% public market equities with a very low basis that goes all the way back to the financial crisis. So the funded vehicle just didn't work for those constraints. And then if you want to integrate well with tax loss harvesting and direct indexing, which are the important trends in the retail world, well, those folks are using SMAs anyway. Right? And we need to be able... We need to be able to interact with that. And in fact, there's some interesting but kind of complex tax efficiencies between derivative strategies and tax loss that you can flesh out if you're both running it as an SMA strategy. So in our view, really, the only way to tick all the boxes on the investment side and really deliver the full power of derivatives, which are an unfunded instrument, is to not put them through a funded intermediation. Right? If you want to give someone the full power of the unfunded thing, you've got to let it be... You've got to let it be unfunded for them. Right? Rather than wrapping it up in a funded vehicle for your own convenience. So then we just said, okay, well, if we're going to do that, what's the technology stack that we need in order to be able to do it at scale and operate it, many custodians with many accounts and many mandates? And so we built a technology infrastructure to be able to do it. And we're really proud of it. It's a combination of Zed's accumulated investment experience and my accumulated technology experience. And it's been working for the last 18 months. We've done, I don't know, something like 17,000 trades or something through this thing. That's working.
